ControlTitle: Preparation - update incident response plan and handling process
ControlDescription:
Ensure your organization follows industry best practice to develop processes and plans to respond to security incidents on the cloud platforms. Be mindful about the shared responsibility model and the variances across IaaS, PaaS, and SaaS services. This will have a direct impact on how you collaborate with your cloud provider in incident response and handling activities, such as incident notification and triage, evidence collection, investigation, eradication, and recovery.

Regularly test the incident response plan and handling process to ensure they're up to date.

Update your organization's incident response process to include the handling of incidents in the Azure platform. Based on the Azure services used and your application nature, customize the incident response plan and playbook to ensure they can be used to respond to the incident in the cloud environment.
Question:
1.	Is there an Azure-specific IR plan covering Sentinel, Defender for Cloud, and AAD?
2.	When was the last IR tabletop exercise conducted?
3.	Are runbooks/playbooks reviewed and updated after plan revisions?
RequiredEvidence:
1.	IR plan version log with last modified timestamp ( SharePoint/Confluence version history ).
2.	Sentinel playbook export: az sentinel automation-rule list -- resource-group <rg> -- workspace-name <ws>
3.	Change history for IR runbooks in Azure Automation ( az automation runbook list .. resource-group <rg> ).
4.	Evidence of simulated attack drill in Sentinel ( SecurityIncident | where Title contains "simulation" ).
EvidenceItems: IR plan version log with last modified timestamp ( SharePoint/Confluence version history ) | Sentinel playbook export: az sentinel automation-rule list -- resource-group <rg> -- workspace-name <ws> | Change history for IR runbooks in Azure Automation ( az automation runbook list .. resource-group <rg> ) | Evidence of simulated attack drill in Sentinel ( SecurityIncident | where Title contains "simulation" )
Notes: Observations: Incident Response Partner manages the Azure Incident response in co-ordination with CONTOSO, assuming that Incident Response Partner will comply to the control implementation & Industry best practises

ControlDescription:
Ensure the security alerts and incident notifications from the cloud service provider's platform and your environments can be received by correct contact in your incident response organization.

Set up security incident contact information in Microsoft Defender for Cloud. This contact information is used by Microsoft to contact you if the Microsoft Security Response Center (MSRC) discovers that your data has been accessed by an unlawful or unauthorized party. You also have options to customize incident alerts and notification in different Azure services based on your incident response needs.
Question:
1.	Is a security contact configured in Defender for Cloud?
2.	Are incident alerts integrated with ticketing (ServiceNow, Jira) or paging (Teams,
PagerDuty)?
3.	Are alternate comms (SMS/email) tested for out-of-band notifications?
RequiredEvidence:
1.	az security contact list -- query "[]. {Email: email, Phone: phone}".
2.	Sentinel alert - Logic App connector export proving ServiceNow integration.
3.	Azure Monitor action group configuration ( az monitor action-group list ).
EvidenceItems: az security contact list -- query "[]. {Email: email, Phone: phone}" | Sentinel alert - Logic App connector export proving ServiceNow integration | Azure Monitor action group configuration ( az monitor action-group list )
Notes:
Observations: Incident Response Partner manages the Azure Incident response in co-ordination with CONTOSO, assuming that Incident Response Partner will comply to the control implementation & Industry best practises
Defender for cloud has email notification set-up

ControlTitle: Detection and analysis - create incidents based on high-quality alerts
ControlDescription:
Ensure you have a process to create high-quality alerts and measure the quality of alerts. This allows you to learn lessons from past incidents and prioritize alerts for analysts, so they don't waste time on false positives.

High-quality alerts can be built based on experience from past incidents, validated community sources, and tools designed to generate and clean up alerts by fusing and correlating diverse signal sources.

Microsoft Defender for Cloud provides high-quality alerts across many Azure assets. You can use the Microsoft Defender for Cloud data connector to stream the alerts to Microsoft Sentinel. Microsoft Sentinel lets you create advanced alert rules to generate incidents automatically for an investigation.

Export your Microsoft Defender for Cloud alerts and recommendations using the export feature to help identify risks to Azure resources. Export alerts and recommendations either manually or in an ongoing, continuous fashion.
Question:
1.	Are Microsoft Defender alerts automatically converted into Sentinel incidents?
2.	Is there deduplication/correlation to prevent alert flooding?
3.	How is fidelity measured (false positives, true positives)?
4.	Are alerts prioritized against MITRE ATT&CK techniques?
RequiredEvidence:
1.	Sentinel analytics rule export ( az sentinel alert-rule list ).
2.	Incident export where ProviderName == "Microsoft. Security".
3.	KQL correlation query: Kusto : SecurityIncident | summarize count() by AlertProductNames
4.	MITRE ATT&CK mapping workbook screenshot from Sentinel.
5.	Log Analytics query showing false positive suppression rates.
EvidenceItems: Sentinel analytics rule export ( az sentinel alert-rule list ) | Incident export where ProviderName == "Microsoft. Security" | KQL correlation query: Kusto : SecurityIncident | summarize count() by AlertProductNames | MITRE ATT&CK mapping workbook screenshot from Sentinel | Log Analytics query showing false positive suppression rates
Notes:
Observations: Incident Response Partner manages the Azure Incident response in co-ordination with CONTOSO, assuming that Incident Response Partner will comply to the control implementation & Industry best practises

ControlTitle: Detection and analysis - investigate an incident
ControlDescription:
Ensure the security operation team can query and use diverse data sources as they investigate potential incidents, to build a full view of what happened. Diverse logs should be collected to track the activities of a potential attacker across the kill chain to avoid blind spots. You should also ensure insights and learnings are captured for other analysts and for future historical reference.

Use the cloud native SIEM and incident management solution if your organization does not have an existing solution to aggregate security logs and alerts information. Correlate incident data based on the data sourced from different sources to facility the incident investigations.

Ensure your security operations team can query and use diverse data sources that are collected from the in-scope services and systems. In addition, it sources can also include:

Identity and access log data: Use Azure AD logs and workload (such as operating systems or application level) access logs for correlating identity and access events.
Network data: Use network security groups' flow logs, Azure Network Watcher, and Azure Monitor to capture network flow logs and other analytics information.
Incident related activity data of from snapshots of the impacted systems, which can be obtained through:
The azure virtual machine's snapshots capability, to create a snapshot of the running system's disk.
The operating system's native memory dump capability, to create a snapshot of the running system's memory.
The snapshot feature of other supported Azure services or your software's own capability, to create snapshots of the running systems.
Microsoft Sentinel provides extensive data analytics across virtually any log source and a case management portal to manage the full lifecycle of incidents. Intelligence information during an investigation can be associated with an incident for tracking and reporting purposes.
Question:
1.	Are telemetry sources (AAD sign-in, NSG flows, VM OS logs) ingested into Sentinel?
2.	Are snapshots and forensic images taken during investigation?
3.	Do analysts use standardized KQL queries/playbooks?
RequiredEvidence:
1.	Sample KQL queries run during last incident investigation.
2.	NSG flow log JSON export ( az network watcher flow-log show ).
3.	VM snapshot list ( az snapshot list -- resource-group <rg> ).
4.	Immutable storage container listing forensic memory dumps.
EvidenceItems: Sample KQL queries run during last incident investigation | NSG flow log JSON export ( az network watcher flow-log show ) | VM snapshot list ( az snapshot list -- resource-group <rg> ) | Immutable storage container listing forensic memory dumps
Notes:
Observations: Investigation hub: Google SecOps (Chronicle) as primary query/correlation plane
Ingestion/normalization: Cribl routes and normalizes logs to Chronicle; basic field mapping in place.
Incident Response Partner manages the Azure Incident response in co-ordination with CONTOSO, assuming that Incident Response Partner will comply to the control implementation & Industry best practises

ControlDescription:
Provide context to security operations teams to help them determine which incidents ought to first be focused on, based on alert severity and asset sensitivity defined in your organizationâ€™s incident response plan.

Additionally, mark resources using tags and create a naming system to identify and categorize your cloud resources, especially those processing sensitive data. It is your responsibility to prioritize the remediation of alerts based on the criticality of the resources and environment where the incident occurred.

Microsoft Defender for Cloud assigns a severity to each alert to help you prioritize which alerts should be investigated first. The severity is based on how confident Microsoft Defender for Cloud is in the finding or the analytics used to issue the alert, as well as the confidence level that there was malicious intent behind the activity that led to the alert.

Similarly, Microsoft Sentinel creates alerts and incidents with an assigned severity and other details based on analytics rules. Use analytic rule templates and customize the rules according to your organization's needs to support incident prioritization. Use automation rules in Microsoft Sentinel to manage and orchestrate threat response in order to maximize your security operation's team efficiency and effectiveness, including tagging incidents to classify them.
Question:
1.	How are severity levels defined (system default vs custom rules)?
2.	Are incidents tied to asset tags or business impact classifications?
3.	Are SLA response times enforced across severities?
4.	How are repeated incidents prioritized differently from new ones?
RequiredEvidence:
1.	Sentinel incident export with severity metadata.
2.	Azure Resource Graph query: Kusto : Resources | where tags. CriticalAsset == "true"
3.	SLA compliance metrics from SOC ticketing integration.
4.	Sentinel incident timeline export showing "repeat offenders."
EvidenceItems: Sentinel incident export with severity metadata | Azure Resource Graph query: Kusto : Resources | where tags. CriticalAsset == "true" | SLA compliance metrics from SOC ticketing integration | Sentinel incident timeline export showing "repeat offenders."
Notes: Observations: Incident Response Partner manages the Azure Incident response in co-ordination with CONTOSO, assuming that Incident Response Partner will comply to the control implementation & Industry best practises

ControlTitle: Containment, eradication and recovery - automate the incident handling
ControlDescription:
Automate the manual, repetitive tasks to speed up response time and reduce the burden on analysts. Manual tasks take longer to execute, slowing each incident and reducing how many incidents an analyst can handle. Manual tasks also increase analyst fatigue, which increases the risk of human error that causes delays and degrades the ability of analysts to focus effectively on complex tasks.

Use workflow automation features in Microsoft Defender for Cloud and Microsoft Sentinel to automatically trigger actions or run a playbooks to respond to incoming security alerts. Playbooks take actions, such as sending notifications, disabling accounts, and isolating problematic networks.
Question:
1.	Which incidents trigger automated SOAR playbooks?
2.	What containment steps are executed automatically (block IP, isolate VM, disable account)?
3.	How are manual approvals integrated into automated flows?
RequiredEvidence:
1.	Sentinel automation rule JSON export.
2.	Logic App runbook execution log for VM isolation.
3.	Azure AD audit logs: Kusto: AuditLogs | where ActivityDisplayName == "Block user"
4.	Approval logs/screenshots from playbooks requiring analyst confirmation.
EvidenceItems: Sentinel automation rule JSON export | Logic App runbook execution log for VM isolation | Azure AD audit logs: Kusto: AuditLogs | where ActivityDisplayName == "Block user" | Approval logs/screenshots from playbooks requiring analyst confirmation
Notes:
Observations: SOAR: Google SecOps

ControlTitle: Post-incident activity - conduct lessons learned and retain evidence
ControlDescription:
Conduct lessons learned in your organization periodically and/or after major incidents, to improve your future capability in incident response and handling.

Based on the nature of the incident, retain the evidence related to the incident for the period defined in the incident handling standard for further analysis or legal actions.

Use the outcome from the lessons learned activity to update your incident response plan, playbook (such as a Microsoft Sentinel playbook) and reincorporate findings into your environments (such as logging and threat detection to address any gaps in logging) to improve your future capability in detecting, responding, and handling of incidents in Azure.

Keep the evidence collected during the "Detection and analysis - investigate an incident step" such as system logs, network traffic dumps and running system snapshots in storage such as an Azure Storage account for immutable retention.
Question:
1.	Are formal lessons-learned meetings conducted post-incident?
2.	Is the IR plan/playbooks updated as a result of those findings?
3.	Are forensic artifacts archived immutably?
4.	How are learnings fed back into detection logic (rules, hunting queries)?
5.	Is training updated for analysts after incidents?
RequiredEvidence:
1.	Post-mortem report (export PDF from ticketing/Confluence).
2.	Sentinel playbook change log ( az resource show .. ).
3.	Storage immutability policy ( az storage container immutability-policy show ).
4.	Updated Sentinel analytics rule JSON dated after the incident.
5.	SOC training records showing refreshed scenarios.
EvidenceItems: Post-mortem report (export PDF from ticketing/Confluence) | Sentinel playbook change log ( az resource show .. ) | Storage immutability policy ( az storage container immutability-policy show ) | Updated Sentinel analytics rule JSON dated after the incident | SOC training records showing refreshed scenarios
